Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: An attorney in a case before you has just cited a new appellate court decision from last week that could be relevant. You need to review it before the next session.
Story: I sat at my desk, the thick file of the ongoing case open before me, when my phone buzzed. It was a message from my younger sister: “Can you call? I really need to talk.” I knew she’d been struggling lately, and as her brother, I’d always promised to be there when she needed me. But just then, the attorney in the courtroom had cited a new appellate decision from last week—one I hadn’t yet read. As a judge, I was expected to be fully prepared, to know the latest legal precedents before the next session tomorrow. My mind raced. If I called my sister now, I’d lose precious time to review the case law. If I ignored her, I’d be breaking the unspoken promise we’d always shared. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, each too important to neglect. I stared at my phone, torn, feeling the tension coil tighter inside me.
